title: Is it true to say that Japan's invasion of Manchuria on September 18, 1931 started World War II? Why or why not? - Quora

response.answer_text: As User-13700852869600268893 states, not technically. But it’s quite all right in my book to say so, because for the involved populations, it is not distinct from the war itself. Also, on a related subject, if you travel to Italy and have a look at a monument in tribute to the fallen in WWI, you’ll notice that the monument generally states that the war lasted from 1915 to 1918, instead of the widely taught 1914–1918: Italy stayed neutral until 1915. And if you look for information on the “Great patriotic war” that opposed the USSR to Nazi Germany, you’ll notice that while it’s accepted as a part of World War II, which lasted from 1939 (Poland) to 1945 (German and Japanese defeats), the Soviets usually date it 1941 to 1945: they were out of it until invaded in Operation Barbarossa. Here is an image of a commemorative postage stamp celebrating the 20th anniversary of Stalingrad - look at the dates:  So it’s not entirely correct, but not really wrong either.
